item.title: WWDC2020: What's new in CryptoKit
item.description: CryptoKit, introduced in WWDC2019, allows us to perform cryptographic operations very easily. While CryptoKit still doesn’t offer many algorithms and functionality, it’s still growing, and this year CryptoKit and do more. HKDF Key derivation functions have been available from day one, but it wasn’t possible to derive keys independently. It was only possible to do so if you were using elliptic curve key agreement protocols. To do this, there is a new HKDF object with static methods.

item.title: CryptoKit and the Secure Enclave
item.description: CryptoKit and the Secure Enclave Apple’s CryptoKit introduced this year is full of amazing features. Not only does it offer very easy to use cryptography, but it also offers an interface to a security feature that Apple introduced less than a decade ago: The Secure Enclave. The Secure Enclave is a hardware feature for helping the system work with cryptographically secure data. In this article, we will build upon our previous CryptoKit knowledge (see the article linked above), and we will also learn what the Secure Enclave is all about.

item.title: Common Cryptographic Operations With CryptoKit
item.description: Apple has always taken security very seriously, so it’s expected that they would provide developers with the same tools they have to help developers implement the same security measures in their apps. This year, Apple introduced CryptoKit. Apple providing new cryptography tools is nothing new. They have provided the Security framework for a very long time, and a few years later they introduced CommonCrypto. The problem with these frameworks is that they can be very low level, being written in C, and it can be intimidating for new developers to adopt them in their project.
